Alejandro Murrieta.Action: Grabs Joaquin to quickly hide and avoid getting caught, showing protective instinct.
Encourages moving closer to observe, demonstrating eagerness but potentially risky for others.
Suggests moving closer to better observe the situation, shows initiative and situational awareness.
Carefully crawls through the crowd and tries to avoid detection, demonstrating stealth and tactical thinking.
Attempts to escape after being spotted by a monk figure, showing quick reaction and awareness.
Scrambles back to Joaquin quickly upon realizing Zorro is near, uses a finger-to-lips gesture to silently alert his companion.
Looks around in wonder, amazed at Zorro's disappearing trick, showing a reactive rather than an anticipatory mindset.
Spots Zorro and recognizes him quickly during a dangerous rescue attempt, showing attentiveness and support for the cause.
Scrambles across a roof to presumably aid prisoners about to be executed, demonstrating courage and willingness to help others.
Scrambles across a roof under threat, actively searching for Zorro; quickly spots Zorro entering the scene, indicating alertness and situational awareness.
Relies on Zorro’s intervention rather than acting independently to stop the firing squad, showing some dependence on others for critical action.
Hurries to warn Zorro of the ambush, actively helps by pushing a heavy brick onto soldiers.
Reaches for Zorro’s medallion but does not insist or cause conflict when Joaquin takes it instead.
Reaches out to touch the medallion lightly and reverently after Joaquin lifts it, showing respect and awareness of its significance but not taking immediate action to claim it.

No direct action or mention in this excerpt; however, implicit association with Diego and others showing concern and defense.
Endures captivity alongside his brother Joaquin without complaint or bitterness.
Maintains a defeated glance shared with his brother, indicating empathy and solidarity.
No direct interaction or expressions toward others in this excerpt.
Warns Joaquin to drop down and keeps slack on rope to avoid choking him during fight.
Questions the reward amount, suggesting it’s insulting and advises Jack not to accept it out of respect for his efforts.
Questions the soldiers about the reward, displaying awareness of his situation and value.
Notices the soldiers' distraction and uses it to take tactical action by dropping to his knees and managing the rope to trip soldiers.
Subdues two soldiers skillfully after tripping them, showing physical capability and quick thinking.
Chuckles at Joaquin's deflated reaction, flicks the reins with a grin.
Makes peasants turn their pockets inside-out, not impressed.
Does not warn Joaquin about the incoming shot despite Joaquin yelling for a warning.
Keeps a grip on the rope with controlled slack to avoid choking himself while restraining Joaquin and subduing soldiers swiftly.
Does not warn Joaquin about the approaching danger, resulting in Joaquin being disarmed easily.
Efficiently searches soldiers' pockets immediately after the conflict, showing focus on gathering intelligence.
Remains unbothered and pragmatic about Jack wanting respect, not escalating unnecessary conflict with peasants.
Chuckles at Joaquin's failed attempt to imitate Zorro and confidently takes the lead driving the wagon away.
Refuses to share the gold with the mission, insists on keeping it all for themselves.
Voices skepticism about idealism represented by Zorro, showing distrust towards others' intentions.
Eventually accepts Joaquin's suggestion to honor Zorro by riding to the mission, showing willingness to respect group values.
Examines the gold ingot and argues confidently about the risks involved in taking the gold and running, showing awareness of the consequences and a realistic assessment of their situation.
Dismisses Joaquin's idealistic view and practical advice about giving half to the mission, showing impatience and shortsightedness.
No direct actions or statements in this excerpt to evaluate warmth.
No direct action or statement present in the excerpt; no indication of competence or incompetence observed.
Shows no direct interaction or concern in this segment, focused on Diego's actions instead.
Creates a makeshift explosive device using available materials to escape manacles, showing resourcefulness and bravery despite injury.
Lays on a bedroll at the campfire while others stand guard or take action.
Responds to Jack's boast about indulgent plans with a modest, self-deprecating comment.
Declines to boast about wealth or status, chooses to keep his 'sefiorita' instead of the horse.
Initially reacts defensively by diving for his gun when threatened.
Dives for his gun immediately upon hearing a crack in the darkness, showing alertness and readiness.
Stops short when confronted with a bayonet at his face, displaying good awareness to avoid a potentially fatal mistake.
Responds quickly by kicking away the rifle pointed at him, showing quick reflexes and confidence.
Uses burning logs to create chaos and help his group escape, showing quick thinking and protective behavior.
Engages in violent combat with soldiers, including targeting and injuring enemies to protect himself and others.
Flinches upon seeing a gun but recovers quickly and defeats the armed opponent, then takes the soldier's lantern to aid his escape.
Knocks out a soldier silently, takes his weapons, and extinguishes the lantern to aid in escape.
Smiles looking through sights after shooting an enemy soldier.
Sneaks up on and knocks out an enemy soldier, steals his weapons, and extinguishes the lantern to prevent enemy alert.
Takes a well-aimed shot killing an enemy soldier threatening Joaquin.
Shouts Joaquin's name in shock and fury after Joaquin is wounded.
Fires at Love in a desperate attempt to protect or avenge Joaquin.
Leaps to defend himself against soldiers and fights aggressively, showing determination to protect himself or others.
Breaks from hiding in a furious reaction, fires a pistol at Love, showing impulsiveness but determination.
Leaps for the rider hunting him, knocks him off his horse, performs a trick-riding mount, and reins the horse around to face Love, demonstrating physical skill and quick thinking.
Reacts with shock and fury when Joaquin is injured, possibly compromising his tactical judgment.
No direct action or statement by Alejandro Murrieta in this excerpt; primarily other characters' interactions.
Cries privately at the site of Joaquin's death, showing vulnerability and mourning.
Offers the medallion to the bartender in place of money, demonstrating trust and sincerity despite his lack of cash.
Finds Joaquin's sword and medallion, shows emotional depth but is alone and exhausted at the site of death.
Attempts to pay for whiskey with medallion, unsure of its value, tries to barter but lacks certainty.
Displays quick thinking by using medallion to try to trade for drink despite lack of money.
Reveals his brother is dead and vows revenge on his killer.
Responds to Diego's warnings with hostility, telling him to go away and shoving him aside.
Ignores Diego's attempts to help and refuses to listen, showing impatience and anger.
Makes a vow of revenge and immediately acts on it by grabbing the sword and walking away without hesitation.
Ignores advice and warnings from Diego about the dangers of revenge and his own readiness.
Responds to Diego's question about knowing how to use the sword with an overly simplistic and naive answer ('The pointy end goes in the other guy').
Attempts to fight Diego using brute strength and multiple slashes, but fails to land a hit, showing lack of skill in swordplay.
Acts confidently and decisively in pursuing his goal despite being physically overpowered and outclassed in skill during the sparring with Diego.
Looks at Diego with respect after being disarmed and threatened.
Agrees to learn from Diego despite suspicion, showing openness and willingness to trust.
Accepts the sword and medallion from Diego and vows to care for them, indicating sincerity and respect.
Attempts a straight thrust attack, despite prior failed attempts, showing persistence and willingness to engage skillfully.
Gets disarmed and tripped by Diego, ends up flat on his back with sword at throat.
Stares up at Diego amazed, then calmly agrees to learn from him despite the humiliating defeat.
Negotiates the terms of training and shows readiness to do anything necessary to become capable.
Passively accepts Diego's lead and instructions, showing willingness to learn and follow guidance.
Surveys the cave with awe and curiosity, asks questions about their purpose.
Obeys Diego's sharp command without hesitation.
Stares in awe at the dais and complex designs, lifting the medallion to compare and recognizing its similarity.
Asks relevant questions about the place and their purpose, showing curiosity and willingness to learn.
Shows confidence with the statement 'You are Zorro' after absorbing initial information.
Obeys Diego's sharp command immediately without hesitation.
Complies with Diego's corrections and training despite struggles and physical discomfort.
Shows eagerness and humility by asking 'When do we begin?' and accepting Diego's authority.
Takes initiative by reaching for the sword when told to train, demonstrating responsibility and engagement.
Smiles with satisfaction when his stance is perfect after training.
Gives Diego a sidelong glance after an instruction, showing subtle humor or rapport.
Fumbles with sword grip but persists in learning.
Leaves the wagon to investigate the commotion, showing curiosity and willingness to engage.
Clenches fists, ready for revenge, expresses anger and hatred.
Leaps from the wagon promptly upon hearing commotion and goes to investigate.
Stays in the shadows, observing the Indians struggling with the horse.
Clenches fists, ready for revenge immediately, showing impulsive emotional response rather than calm judgment.
Dismisses Diego’s warning about revealing anger and hatred, indicating a lack of strategic thinking.
Baits Diego playfully about Zorro's horse with a smile exchanged between them.
Smiles at Elena and makes a gentle 'Shhh' gesture to calm her and her horse.
Baits Diego by joking about the horse being Zorro's horse, showing quick wit and confidence.
Wears the Zorro outfit convincingly, surprises Elena with a confident smile, and skillfully quiets her horse, demonstrating composure and control.
Nods impatiently when Diego advises him, indicating possible impatience or disregard for guidance.

Successfully breaks into the stables undetected, shows calmness and skill in handling a difficult horse, maintains control despite the horse's violent bucking, and uses the horse's behavior strategically to create chaos and achieve his goal.
Grabs gold ingots quickly and plans an escape by lassoing the strongbox to the horse's saddle horn.
Responds rapidly by drawing pistols and firing them with lightning speed during the escape.
Remains alert to immediate threats and relies on the horse's instinct to defend him by kicking a soldier.
Fails to prevent the horse from being caught between support beams and losing control, resulting in a near capture and the horse breaking through the beams.
Knocked off the horse due to low door clearance but quickly recovers and runs from soldiers.
Seeks sanctuary in the church and does not harm Fray Felipe when confronted; accepts Felipe's help without hostility.
Silences Fray Felipe by putting a hand over his mouth to prevent yelling but releases him quickly when recognized.
Initially avoids engaging with Elena’s confession and attempts to evade interaction.
Listens attentively and empathetically to Elena's confession and feelings, engaging sincerely with her emotions.
Draws his sword quickly upon sensing trouble, demonstrates readiness and alertness.

Takes control of a wild horse by jumping from a roof and riding it confidently.
Manages to break into the cuartel, creating significant damage and chaos, indicating effective sabotage skills.
Carves a clear and confident 'Z' mark, demonstrating skill with a sword.
Rescues some Indians during a risky gold heist, showing concern beyond himself.
Expresses frustration and impatience with waiting for revenge, indicating intense personal focus.
Gratefully accepts Diego's approval and instruction, showing respect and a willingness to learn.
Successfully steals a horse and gold, drags a strong box into the cave, and rescues some Indians, despite disapproval from Diego.

Resignedly takes the fork despite uncertainty, showing willingness to learn.

Responds with self-doubt about his confidence, exchanges a candid, slightly humorous conversation with Diego about being charming.
Dismounts from horse in impressive finery, confidently strides forward, makes a strong first impression.
Pauses and questions how the deception will work after learning about the nonexistence of Bartolo's heir.
Ignores a servant's outstretched hand and confidently approaches Montero to establish presence.
Delivers formal greeting and answers Montero’s questions smoothly, showing knowledge and preparation.
Relies on rote lines and instructions from Diego without fully masking own doubts.
Engages confidently in social interaction, presenting himself well to Montero and guests, performs a magic trick to impress and ease tension.
Quickly recovers from an initial slight rejection, skillfully turns it around by showing charm and wit.
Leads Diego authoritatively by calling him promptly and directing him to attend.

Light-heartedly jokes about ordering Diego around; engages politely with Elena and others at the table; uses courteous language such as 'Good evening' and 'Pleased to meet you.'
Commands Diego brusquely with 'No more back talk! Do as you're told.'
Acknowledges the difficulty of finding good help, showing a modest appreciation for others.
Helps Elena into her chair, showing attentiveness and polite consideration.
Looks down bewildered at the vast array of table settings, unsure which knife to use, then resignedly eats the roll dry.

Waltzes beautifully with Elena, engages playfully and intimately, challenges her in a friendly way.
Pulls Elena close in a bold, sensual dance, disregarding other dancers but shares an intimate moment.
Acknowledges Elena's trust by promising to keep her secret and shows he is improving at it.
Does not appear to consider or respect the discomfort of the protective fathers watching the dance.

Engages in bold flirtation with Elena despite the presence of her protective father and others, showing social confidence but risking confrontation.

Deflects blame onto Elena to calm Montero and avoid angering him.
Responds politely to Montero's apology and accepts social interaction graciously.
Smiles when invited by Montero to join the group, showing openness and friendliness.
Disengages from Elena immediately and adopts a respectful demeanor, feigns surprise and quickly defuses Montero’s anger by taking blame subtly.
Successfully convinces Montero that he was startled and that Elena is at fault, causing Montero to forgive the perceived offense.
Shows social awareness and quick thinking in a tense situation, maintaining composure and gaining Montero's acceptance and invitation.
Draws a breath in response to Montero's plan, showing attentiveness but no direct involvement or strategic thinking.
Makes a sarcastic remark about Santa Anna's IOUs, causing laughter and camaraderie among the group.

Makes a witty, confident remark about Santa Anna's IOUs, lightening the mood and demonstrating social ease and awareness.

Spreads his hands in a ‘how about me?' gesture, showing engagement and openness in social setting.
Observes the harsh conditions of men in chains working the gold mines with apparent concern and attentiveness.

Stares in horror at Jack's corpse after he is shot and killed.
Raises an eyebrow and cynically observes that a man would have to be crazy to protest the planned oppression of the workers.
Allows Montero to slap his back and heads back to the coaches with the oppressors, seemingly conforming outwardly.
Reasserts control after witnessing a traumatic event, keeping his gaze unreadable and composed.
Raises an eyebrow and calmly assesses the situation with the workers, guards, and dead man, demonstrating situational awareness.
Responds with a logical, confident statement on why protesting the situation would be unwise, showing insight and decisiveness.

Smiles, shrugs, and agrees to follow soldiers despite suspicion; shows good-natured compliance

Responds calmly and with subtle humor to Love's ominous threats and gestures.

Responds to Love's insinuations with calm and wit, asking if Love will share his secret.
Maintains composure despite being confronted with the shocking sight of Joaquin Murrieta's pickled head.

Makes a light, somewhat joking comment about his brother being an irate husband, signaling a friendly, tolerant attitude.
Expresses recognition of Love's cruelty by calling him a monster, showing emotional sincerity and trust in Diego.
Remains unfazed and drinks brine from the jar containing his brother's head, maintaining composure and showing courage under psychological pressure.
Engages in calm, witty dialogue with Captain Love, indicating intelligence and social confidence.

Examines gold and armor carefully, noticing details such as the burned corner and the name plate, showing attention to detail and cautious investigation.

Avoids capture by quickly bolting and leading a pursuit through the estate.
Realizes the presence of enemies quickly and attempts escape without hesitation.
Encountering Montero unexpectedly causes Montero to be horrified, indicating Alejandro’s imposing or skilled reputation.
Nearly caught when spotted by Love because he fails to notice or anticipate the mirror reflecting his position.

Uses agility and quick thinking to escape pursuers by cutting a soldier's belt to make him fall; swings to the next balcony and fights multiple soldiers efficiently with a fluid and flamboyant fighting style.
Keeps calm under pressure, effectively dodges and counters multiple attacks while surrounded by enemies, demonstrates confidence and skill in combat.
Leaps onto a bell, uses it as cover while under rifle fire, indicating tactical awareness and adaptability.
Protects the horse by knocking out a soldier who threatened it.
Confronts Elena with a mix of humor and respect, salutes her after a fencing exchange.
Deceives others by pretending to be a priest, indicating manipulative behavior.
Swings on the bell pull rope over a soldier's head, kicks him, back-flips to the ground, and dashes away.
Bangs his fist against a stall to startle a horse, which then kicks out and incapacitates a soldier.
Engages in a swordfight with Elena; initially surprised but quickly draws his sword to defend himself and then attacks seriously.
Laughs off Elena aiming a sword at him and confidently approaches the door despite the threat.
He parries and swipes skillfully during the fight, uses boots and spurs effectively to defend and disarm Elena.
He is disarmed unexpectedly when Elena catches his blade in her robe and twists it, sending his sword flying.
He quickly recovers from being disarmed by rolling, wrenching the sword back, and continuing the fight confidently.
He loses his hat and gets a gash on his pants during the duel, indicating moments of vulnerability.
Effortlessly disarms opponent by snapping her sword into the ceiling and uses agility to escape pursuing soldiers using the ladder and deft parries.
Maintains calm composure, confident demeanor, and strategic thinking during confrontation and escape.
Briefly pauses affectionate moment to make a quick and calculated exit from dangerous situation.
Dodges and fights guards fiercely while avoiding lethal harm to opponents, uses environment tactically.
Pauses quietly and observes a fox in the midst of intense pursuit, showing a thoughtful, serene reaction.
Grins at enemy and punches him, knocking him off horse during chase.
Quickly recovers from being thrown off his horse and uses the environment to his advantage by casting a riata, then swinging onto another horse in the pursuing troop.
Takes out multiple horse riders one by one while moving quickly through the horse chase.
Knocks out Corporal Lopez and anticipates a fallen tree, successfully jumping the horse over it.
Despite the dangerous situation and being pursued, maintains composure and tactical thinking, outmaneuvering enemies.
Confidently assesses the guarded canyon on the map and asserts 'we can handle them,' showing strategic understanding and confidence.
Insists that prisoners should not be sacrificed and shows concern for their lives, despite Diego's pragmatism.
Confronts Diego with sincerity and challenges his cold calculation, revealing his belief in protecting people and honorable motives.
Shows vulnerability and doubt about revenge, acknowledging complexity beyond hatred.
Cuts in front of Diego, physically blocking him, initiating what resembles a duel, showing assertiveness but possible tension.
Tells Diego to save Elena and protect the innocent as long as Zorro is alive.
Shoves Diego away after Diego warns him urgently.
Rejects Diego’s claim that he is a weapon and credits him for teaching him to be Zorro.
Questions Diego's assumptions and decides to ride alone to the mine, showing initiative and decisiveness.
Shoves Diego away after a serious warning about imminent danger, potentially disregarding critical advice.
Responds confidently and assertively to Diego, affirming his identity as Zorro rather than a mere weapon, showing self-awareness and confidence.
Helps Fray Felipe up after rescuing him, offers a reassuring smile to intimidate the sadistic soldier.
Riskily intervenes to stop cruelty to prisoners, showing concern for others' suffering.
Disguises himself as Zorro, silently infiltrates enemy area by hopping onto a lowering platform to approach prisoners unnoticed.
Maintains calm and careful observation from a concealed position, assessing the situation before acting.
Runs through a sadistic soldier who threatens a priest and offers help to the priest immediately after, showing decisive and skilled combat ability.
Kills two soldiers in combat, but spares another soldier by indirectly causing his death rather than attacking him directly.
Helps the little girl by giving her his medallion and verbally reassures her no one is going to die.
Defends and guards the escape route to ensure the slaves' safety, demonstrating protective behavior.
Moves with grace and economy, skillfully taking on multiple soldiers at once.
Uses surroundings cleverly, pushing the ore car to defeat an enemy and causing another soldier to be crushed by the counterweight.
Maintains calm and tactical awareness under pressure, helping the girl who aids him by giving her his medallion and reassuring her.
Relies on Tornado to save him by grabbing reins, shows limited immediate physical capability in hanging from canyon wall.
Warns Montero to get out immediately despite being under threat, showing quick judgment and bravery.
Gets physically overpowered and taken prisoner without apparent resistance.
Catches Pox's elbow and uses his strength and skill to prevent him from drawing his sword repeatedly, then disarms Pox and holds the sword at his throat with confidence and control.
Engages in a skilled sword duel with Montero despite physical disadvantages, using speed and quick reflexes.
Takes the risk to carry the pouch with a map and deliver it to Santa Anna, showing confidence and purpose.
Conceals the pouch in his belt during the confrontation with Montero as a strategic move.
Confidently claims to be Zorro in a tense moment, showing assertiveness and taking control.
Appears at a critical moment as a decisive presence, indicating readiness and composure.
Reveals his identity and connection to Joaquin, showing sincerity.
Offers mercy to Love by asking him to lay down his sword.
Fights fiercely and uses clever tactics to survive, showing determination but little direct friendliness.
Strips off his mask to reveal his identity, showing courage and confidence in the fight.
Engages in expert sword fighting against multiple opponents, displaying skill and resilience.
Fights blind after being slashed across the eyes but continues to resist and ultimately uses quick thinking to cause Love to fall down the stairs.
Momentarily staggers and goes down to one knee after being attacked, indicating vulnerability.
Quickly intervenes to protect Diego by attacking Montero, risking his own safety.
Sees Montero aiming a deadly strike and quickly intervenes, slashing Montero's arm and disarming him, showing fast reaction and swordsmanship skill.
Engages in a chaotic fight with Love, managing to parry and hold his ground despite being physically disadvantaged, demonstrating fighting capability and resilience.
Falls from the gallery but manages to haul himself partially up while under pressure from an opponent, showing physical endurance and determination.
Gathers Elena in his arms after a violent event.
Offers explanation calmly and cooperatively to Santa Anna during accusation.
Calmly presents the map pouch to Santa Anna to prevent immediate violence and justify their actions.
Physically supported by Diego, suggesting possible temporary weakness or injury after confrontation.
